Description: Body sherd of Chian pottery open vessel, possibly a Wild Goat Style or Mature Animal Style phallus cup; cream slip; interior glazed with two white lines running down from wider upper to narrower lower body; exterior: lotus flower pattern above tongue pattern frieze around neck, tongues alternately reserved and black.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos does not identify the shape of this vessel, but places it within the Chalice Style. The shape is similar to 1924,1201.203, which Williams identified as possibly belonging to a phallus cup (Williams 2006, 128). Phallus cups are rare and only known in the Wild Goat and Animal Chalice Styles.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 2, pl. 3, no. 7)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 307, no. 1254, pl. 161)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1931) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
